Trial_Design.evidence: A stepped-wedge randomized cluster trial was conducted in 12 Dutch hospitals, each representing a cluster.

Participants.evidence: Patients who underwent the quilt technique after mastectomy were compared with those with conventional closure.

Intervention.evidence: Patients who underwent the quilt technique after mastectomy were compared with those with conventional closure.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the implementation of the quilt technique on textbook outcome in patients undergoing mastectomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcome was textbook outcome, defined as the absence of wound complications, readmissions, reoperations, or unscheduled outpatient visits, and no increase in pain medication use 6 months after surgery compared to preoperative use.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: A stepped-wedge randomized cluster trial was conducted in 12 Dutch hospitals, each representing a cluster.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Two hundred and fifty-one patients who underwent mastectomy were included.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of textbook outcome was higher in the quilted cohort compared to the non-quilted cohort, 94 of 143 (65.7%) versus 26 of 63 patients (41.3%, P = 0.003).

Harms.evidence: Wound complications, including clinically significant seroma, were 24.0% in the quilted patients versus 55.6% in the non-quilted patients ( P < 0.001).
